Norman Thomas was named as
the preference of a plurality of the
members of the Johns Hopkins
University faculty at Homewood
in a Presidential preferential poll
completed late yesterday by the
Liberal Club.

Don Kelly, well-known Hopkins
athlete was yesterday elected president of the Junior Class in one of
the most closely-contested elections
held on the campus. It Was not revealed by Student Council by what
plurality Kelly was named to the
office, but it is believed that the margin was extremely slim. Ballots
were cast by 135 members of the
Junior Class.

ASSEMBLY HEARS
DR. HART DISCUSS
PERSONALITIES
World Can Be Divided Into
Positive And Negative Ones
"Positive and Negative Personalities" was the topic of an address
delivered at the assembly here yesterday by Dr. John R. Hart, Jr.,
chaplain of the University of Pennsylvania.
The world can be divided, he said,
into the two personalities: positive
and negative. Negative personalities, Dr. Hart pointed out, are those
who live on "negations and prohibitions and artificial inhibitions."
Negative Personalities

"These sort of individuals," he
declared, "always think that things
can not be done and meditate on the
difficulties and obstacles in the way,"
and are usually "impolite enough to
interrupt you and point out the fault
in a proposal before you finish making it." They are closed, ingrowing personalities," Dr. Hart remarked, "and do not invite confidences any more than they inspire
achievement."
"This entire complex has been
well treated in modern child psychology. Parents have been warned
scientifically not to flood their children with 'don'ts' and 'can'ts'. They
have been told to use the substitution method, so that instead of telling a child what it can't and mustn't
do, they will point out some constructive activity to take it place ...
A history of our institutions shows
the way the negative has often been
in the ascendancy.

Other Officers

Other officers who were elected
are
JoHN WEEKS, vice-president
TED STERN, secretary
MIKE COHEN, treasurer
J. KERN, sergeant-at-arms.
The polls closed at 1 p. m., but
at 2.30 p. m. the victors were unrevealed. This delay was due, it was
learned, to the necessity for the verification of the class standing of
ten voters in yesterday's election.
For reasons which cannot be disclosed, Student Council yesterday
voted that the tallies for each nominee should not be published in the
campus paper. Kelly has been a
member of the varsity football, basketball, and lacrosse squads since his
freshman year. He is captain of
the basketball team for this season.
Football Players

Weeks and Cohen are members of
this year's football squad. Stern
has been secretary of his class since
he entered the Hopkins.
With the Junior Class election,
the elections for the year 1932-33
closed.

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1932

A U. of M. Senior Speaks

the freshmen should be placed in a class
of their own, distinct from the sophomores, juniors, or seniors, we do not
know. All members of all four undergraduate classes are in college for one
purpose—to pursue studies which will
prepare them for life work. There are
differences in ages, intellectual maturity,
in years of residence, but no other. Those
differences, however, give no reason
for looking upon the frosh as insignificant, or as in need of discipline which is
supposed to insure a better foundation
for future years in college. The firstyear student need not be brow-beaten into
realizing that he is beginning a new
phase of life.
It is absurd to believe that "rat rules"
will discipline the new students. The
freshmen realize that they must obey,
to a certain degree, the rules set down—
or else. Everything they do—if they do
the things required of them—is done because of the regulations imposed, not because the men feel they should adhere to
the rules. Discipline? We wonder!
When the sophomore year rolls 'round
the spirit of friendliness and good will
is in a bad state. There are no more
rules. Do the sophs continue their "hellos" to everyone on the campus? Do the
sophs attend the games en masse, full of
true spirit ? The obvious answer is a
hearty "No!"
Freshmen regulations are childish and
ridiculous. University of Maryland has
sunk to a state of puerility when it turns
to "rat rules" to instill into the campus
a "rah-rah" spirit.

Apologies, Reid
WE owe William Reid, the newlyelected Senior Class president, a public
apology. We made an insinuation in our
editorial of October 25 which, it has been
definitely shown, was unjust to Reid. The
Senior Class head acted as a gentleman
should in regard to this editorial comment and we feel that we should act like
gentlemen and apologize for a very grave
error.
Reid is the ONE exception to our assertion: "Not one man elected or nominated in the class elections this year has
earned the right to an office on the
ground that a representative majority of
his classmates regard him as the bestsuited man for the post." The Engineers
backed Reid, a member of their own
school at Homewood. But many seniors
in the College of Arts and Sciences voted
for Reid, too. He was the choice of his
Class, as far as the votes show. He did
NOT campaign for votes and he did
NOT band together the Engineers. The
Engineers banded together themselves in
order to put over Reid.
In making this public apology for making an unjust statement which included
Reid's name, we do not retract our assertion that no other officer in the four
classes earned the right to head the
groups on the ground that they were the
actual choice of a representative majority
of his classmates.

LETTER/
To The

EDITOP
Contributions to this column are welcomed
from students, faculty, and alumni. All communications must be signed. At the request
of the writer, however, name will not be
published. Publication of a letter does not
signify that this paper is in accord with
views expressed.
This U. of M. Senior Writes Such An
"Excellent" Defense Of Frosh Rules
That We Give Him "Undo Notoriety."

To the Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
Nov. 1, 1932.
While reading your so-called
newspaper, I came upon the blatherings in your editorial column
against the ressurection of the 'rat"
rules at Maryland. I am convinced
that you are as ignorant of the conditions on the Maryland campus, as
you are bombastic in your denunciation. The fine old U. of M. tradition of friendliness and good fellowship between students is instilled
by one of these very Freshman regulations that you have ridiculed.
This rule says—"Freshmen must
speak cheerfully to all members of
the faculty, upper classmen, and
members of their own class." What
has been the result of the enforcement of this rule in the past? I'll
tell you! It has helped the Freshman to find his place on the campus
and the spirit of good will engendered in him, lasts thru his collegiate career.

SWARTHMORE SET
FOR HARD BATTLE
Hopkins Forward Wall Will
Undergo Several
Changes
Nothing daunted by their setback
at the hands of Rutgers, the Johns
Hopkins gridders will endeavor to
start another winning streak tomorrow afternoon when they invade
Swarthmore College. The Jays are
determined to make the Pennsylvarnans the first victims of a victorious march which will carry them
safely through the remaining battles
with Hampden-Sydney and ,the
University of Maryland.
Swarthmore is experiencing one of
the most unsuccessful gridiron campaigns in its long history. The
University of Pennsylvania, Gettysburg, Franklin and Marshall, and
Susquehanna have registered successive victories over the Garnet so
far this season.

Dr. Walter G. Becker, exchange
student from Germany, has completed plans for the reorganization
of the German Club, which will
meet this evening at 8.30 P. M. in
the parlor room of Levering Hall.
Hoping to carry on the work of
the late Baron von Ludwiger, German exchange student in 1930-31,
Dr. Becker has planned to hold regAar informal meetings with unpretentious programs.
At the first
meeting of the Club he will speak
on "Present Day German Literature." He intends to intersperse
the group discussions with German
folk songs.

F. Scott Fitzgerald, author of
such well known novels as "This
Side of Paradise", "The Great
Gatsby", and "The Beautiful and
the Damned", will be one of the
featured speakers at the local meeting of the Student Congress
Against War drive, to be held tomorrow night at 8.30, in the Homewood Friends Meeting House, 3107
N. Charles Street.
Held in conjunction with the Chicago rally of December 28 and 29,
the meeting is sponsored by the
Johns Hopkins Liberal Club, and
the Baltimore District of the
National Students League. Representatives of the Johns Hopkins
University, Goucher College, the
University of Baltimore, Morgan
College, and possibly State Normal
School will participate.

Kansas City Opera Company and

Captain John Silkman
Transferred To Ill.
Captain John M. Silkman, of the
Corps of Engineers, who has been
a member of the Military Science
Department of this University for
the past two years, has been transferred to Rock Island, Illinois,
where he will assume the position
of District Engineer.
This transfer became effective
November 1, 1932, due to the program of economy by which the Military Science Department had to reduce its force by one member.

ASSEMBLY HEARS
DR. HART DISCUSS
PERSONALITIES
World Can Be Divided Into
Positive And Negative Ones
"Positive and Negative Personalities" was the topic of an address
delivered at the assembly here yesterday by Dr. John R. Hart, Jr.,
chaplain of the University of Pennsylvania.
The world can be divided, he said,
into the two personalities: positive
and negative. Negative personalities, Dr. Hart pointed out, are those
who live on "negations and prohibitions and artificial inhibitions."
Negative Personalities

"These sort of individuals," he
declared, "always think that things
can not be done and meditate on the
difficulties and obstacles in the way,"
and are usually "impolite enough to
interrupt you and point out the fault
in a proposal before you finish making it." They are closed, ingrowing personalities," Dr. Hart remarked, "and do not invite confidences any more than they inspire
achievement."
"This entire complex has been
well treated in modern child psychology. Parents have been warned
scientifically not to flood their children with 'don'ts' and 'can'ts'. They
have been told to use the substitution method, so that instead of telling a child what it can't and mustn't
do, they will point out some constructive activity to take it place ...
A history of our institutions shows
the way the negative has often been
in the ascendancy.

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1932

A U. of M. Senior Speaks

the freshmen should be placed in a class
of their own, distinct from the sophomores, juniors, or seniors, we do not
know. All members of all four undergraduate classes are in college for one
purpose—to pursue studies which will
prepare them for life work. There are
differences in ages, intellectual maturity,
in years of residence, but no other. Those
differences, however, give no reason
for looking upon the frosh as insignificant, or as in need of discipline which is
supposed to insure a better foundation
for future years in college. The firstyear student need not be brow-beaten into
realizing that he is beginning a new
phase of life.
It is absurd to believe that "rat rules"
will discipline the new students. The
freshmen realize that they must obey,
to a certain degree, the rules set down—
or else. Everything they do—if they do
the things required of them—is done because of the regulations imposed, not because the men feel they should adhere to
the rules. Discipline? We wonder!
When the sophomore year rolls 'round
the spirit of friendliness and good will
is in a bad state. There are no more
rules. Do the sophs continue their "hellos" to everyone on the campus? Do the
sophs attend the games en masse, full of
true spirit ? The obvious answer is a
hearty "No!"
Freshmen regulations are childish and
ridiculous. University of Maryland has
sunk to a state of puerility when it turns
to "rat rules" to instill into the campus
a "rah-rah" spirit.

Apologies, Reid
WE owe William Reid, the newlyelected Senior Class president, a public
apology. We made an insinuation in our
editorial of October 25 which, it has been
definitely shown, was unjust to Reid. The
Senior Class head acted as a gentleman
should in regard to this editorial comment and we feel that we should act like
gentlemen and apologize for a very grave
error.
Reid is the ONE exception to our assertion: "Not one man elected or nominated in the class elections this year has
earned the right to an office on the
ground that a representative majority of
his classmates regard him as the bestsuited man for the post." The Engineers
backed Reid, a member of their own
school at Homewood. But many seniors
in the College of Arts and Sciences voted
for Reid, too. He was the choice of his
Class, as far as the votes show. He did
NOT campaign for votes and he did
NOT band together the Engineers. The
Engineers banded together themselves in
order to put over Reid.
In making this public apology for making an unjust statement which included
Reid's name, we do not retract our assertion that no other officer in the four
classes earned the right to head the
groups on the ground that they were the
actual choice of a representative majority
of his classmates.

LETTER/
To The

EDITOP
Contributions to this column are welcomed
from students, faculty, and alumni. All communications must be signed. At the request
of the writer, however, name will not be
published. Publication of a letter does not
signify that this paper is in accord with
views expressed.
This U. of M. Senior Writes Such An
"Excellent" Defense Of Frosh Rules
That We Give Him "Undo Notoriety."

To the Editor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
Nov. 1, 1932.
While reading your so-called
newspaper, I came upon the blatherings in your editorial column
against the ressurection of the 'rat"
rules at Maryland. I am convinced
that you are as ignorant of the conditions on the Maryland campus, as
you are bombastic in your denunciation. The fine old U. of M. tradition of friendliness and good fellowship between students is instilled
by one of these very Freshman regulations that you have ridiculed.
This rule says—"Freshmen must
speak cheerfully to all members of
the faculty, upper classmen, and
members of their own class." What
has been the result of the enforcement of this rule in the past? I'll
tell you! It has helped the Freshman to find his place on the campus
and the spirit of good will engendered in him, lasts thru his collegiate career.

JAYS, TO VISIT
SWARTHMORE
FOR GRID FRAY
Hope To Begin New Winning Streak Against
Garnet Tomorrow
SWARTHMORE SET
FOR HARD BATTLE
Hopkins Forward Wall Will
Undergo Several
Changes
Nothing daunted by their setback
at the hands of Rutgers, the Johns
Hopkins gridders will endeavor to
start another winning streak tomorrow afternoon when they invade
Swarthmore College. The Jays are
determined to make the Pennsylvarnans the first victims of a victorious march which will carry them
safely through the remaining battles
with Hampden-Sydney and ,the
University of Maryland.
Swarthmore is experiencing one of
the most unsuccessful gridiron campaigns in its long history. The
University of Pennsylvania, Gettysburg, Franklin and Marshall, and
Susquehanna have registered successive victories over the Garnet so
far this season.

Dr. Walter G. Becker, exchange
student from Germany, has completed plans for the reorganization
of the German Club, which will
meet this evening at 8.30 P. M. in
the parlor room of Levering Hall.
Hoping to carry on the work of
the late Baron von Ludwiger, German exchange student in 1930-31,
Dr. Becker has planned to hold regAar informal meetings with unpretentious programs.
At the first
meeting of the Club he will speak
on "Present Day German Literature." He intends to intersperse
the group discussions with German
folk songs.

F. Scott Fitzgerald, author of
such well known novels as "This
Side of Paradise", "The Great
Gatsby", and "The Beautiful and
the Damned", will be one of the
featured speakers at the local meeting of the Student Congress
Against War drive, to be held tomorrow night at 8.30, in the Homewood Friends Meeting House, 3107
N. Charles Street.
Held in conjunction with the Chicago rally of December 28 and 29,
the meeting is sponsored by the
Johns Hopkins Liberal Club, and
the Baltimore District of the
National Students League. Representatives of the Johns Hopkins
University, Goucher College, the
University of Baltimore, Morgan
College, and possibly State Normal
School will participate.

Kansas City Opera Company and

Captain John Silkman
Transferred To Ill.
Captain John M. Silkman, of the
Corps of Engineers, who has been
a member of the Military Science
Department of this University for
the past two years, has been transferred to Rock Island, Illinois,
where he will assume the position
of District Engineer.
This transfer became effective
November 1, 1932, due to the program of economy by which the Military Science Department had to reduce its force by one member.
